description: Learned borrowing from Latin centum (â€œhundredâ€), attested at least since 1890s. Its use in linguistics is due to it being a canonical example of a word retaining an original velar stop, as opposed to Avestan ğ¬¯ğ¬€ğ¬™ğ¬†ğ¬¨â€ (satÉ™m). Doublet of hundred and satem.

entries.meaning: (Indo-European studies) Referring to an Indo-European language that did not produce sibilants from a series of Proto-Indo-European palatovelar stops.

description: Calque of Sanskrit à¤¶à¤¤à¤• (Å›ataka, â€œa hundred; a satakamâ€). The latter meaning is attested at least since 1991 and is explained by 100-point academic grading in India.

entries.meaning: (Sanskrit and other Indian philology) Satakam, set of one hundred verses connected by the same metre or topic.
examples: Tonda-mandala-sÄtacam, a centum of verses on the Conjeveram country, No. 148, C. M. 73. The sÄtacam is a poem of one hundred stanzas, in its appropriate metre.

entries.meaning: (India) Perfect score on a board exam.
examples: Achyuta Satakam is a centum in Prakrit Language; Devanayaka Panchasat (the fifty on Devanayaka), in sanskrit and several poetical works in Tamil.
